REARRANGEMENT OF ORDER OF
BUSINESS


    Mr Speaker: Is the Prime Minister taking his business motion* now?
* The motion, standing in the name of the Prime Minister, reads as follows:-

    That the proceedings on the motion in regard to a referendum being held for the people to decide between two alternatives of reunification standing in my name, and the motion in the names of the Members for Anson and Queenstown that the people of Singapore shall be asked only one question on Polling Day and that Government shall name Polling Day as a day four weeks from the date of the Order therefor, and another motion in the names of the Members for Queenstown and Upper Serangoon that the House condemns the Government for its dishonest and malicious distortion of the Opposition's stand on the merger issue, shall all be brought to a conclusion at 12 midnight on the 11th July, 1962.


    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Now, Sir.

Column: 918



    Mr Speaker: That business motion, of course, also takes in items 11 and 12 on the Order Paper. Perhaps it would be convenient if there is also a business motion moved under Standing Order 10, paragraph 2 - "That items 11 and 12 on the Order Paper be taken immediately after item 3."

    The Prime Minister: That is not the intention. The intention is that, since it is not anticipated that there will be any debate of any length on items 4 to 10 (since they are all going to Select Committee, except items 4 and 5 which are non-controversial), items 11 and 12 be taken after item 10.

    Mr Speaker: After item 10?

    The Prime Minister: Yes.

    Mr Speaker: In that case the business motion can be "That item 3 be taken after item 10." Is that it?

    The Prime Minister: That is so.

    Mr Speaker: Will the Prime Minster please move?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I move under Standing Order 10 (2), That item 3 on the Order Paper be taken after item 10.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Resolved,

    That item 3 on the Order Paper be taken after item 10.

PROCEEDINGS ON MOTIONS ON
REFERENDUM ON REUIFICATION OF SINGAPORE AND FEDERATION OF MALAYA, REFERENDUM ON
MERGER, AND OPPOSITION'S STAND ON MERGER
(Business Motion)


    The Prime Minister: Sir, I beg to move,

Column: 919



    That the proceedings on the motion in regard to a referendum being held for the people to decide between two alternatives of reunification standing in my name, and the motion in the names of the Members for Anson and Queenstown that the people of Singapore shall be asked only one question on Polling Day and that Government shall name Polling Day as a day four weeks from the date of the Order therefor, and another motion in the names of the Members for Queenstown and Upper Serangoon that the House condemns the Government for its dishonest and malicious distortion of the Opposition's stand on the merger issue, shall all be brought to a conclusion at 12 midnight on the 11th July, 1962. Mr Speaker, Sir, we have estimated a debating time of 2 to 3 days for these three items. They are issues which have already been discussed over and over again at considerable length, and no doubt Members of the Opposition would want some considerable time to restate all their propositions in as interesting a way as I hope they can. Mr Speaker, Sir, it gives us roughly 24 hours of debating time, the House sitting from 2.30 p.m. to 12 midnight on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. However, if the Third Reading of the Referendum Bill finishes earlier today - as I think it would be earlier than 12 midnight - then no doubt the debating time will be suitably extended by the rapidity with which conclusions on the Third Reading are brought to a close.

    Question proposed.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): If it please you, Mr Speaker, you will remember that when the Deputy Prime Minister moved his closure motion with reference to the stages of the Referendum Bill, I urge that it was unnecessary.

    Mr Speaker: Order. It was not really a closure motion; it was a guillotine motion.

    Mr David Marshall: Thank you for your terminological correction, Mr Speaker. Sir, I think I will be proved right - I was certainly proved right as regards the first part as we ended before midnight yesterday - and I am sincerely hoping that I will be proved right as regards the second part, and it would have been much happier if things could have taken their normal course. I do urge with respect, Mr

Column: 920

Speaker, and this might assist the Government - they are conscious that by virtue of their prerogative, and I am not complaining of their prerogative, the Prime Minister has introduced a motion which completely blankets out mine, which is item 11 - the one that I put in with the Member for Queenstown - except for the part thereof which speaks of naming the polling day as four weeks from the date of the Order. Now, Mr Speaker, the issue of four weeks from the date of the Order has been fully discussed in this Assembly - it is true on the basis that, the Bill was a general referendum Bill at the time - but we all recognise that there would be no useful purpose served by rediscussing that issue and, I repeat, I for one am not here to filibuster, Mr Speaker, and since the other part of the motion is covered by the Prime Minister, it is my intention not to move the motion appearing as item No. 11 of the Order Paper, since the Government has anticipated it in the Prime Minister's motion.

    Now, in the light of that statement, perhaps the Government will agree with me that it is highly improbable that we would exceed the time limit indicated of the 11th July and they may well wish to consider postponing consideration of this motion, let us say, till Tuesday the 10th and if they are prepared to accept it, I will be happy, Sir, to move under Standing Order, that this motion do stand adjourned to the 10th of July. I am sure that they are no more happy than I am, Sir, to apply guillotine motions which are unnecessary, and I do suggest that this one is unnecessary, Mr Speaker.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government have always said that they want to allow full discussion, and here again they want to limit our discussions to only a few days.

    The Prime Minister: Point of order, Sir. The point of order being that perhaps the Member for Queenstown may not be aware that he is not necessarily obliged to make a speech just because the Member for Anson has done so, although the Member for Anson has touched upon his motion on the Order Paper, item No, 11, I think. So Mr Speaker, Sir, perhaps you can give the Member for Queenstown

Column: 921

and the House a ruling that no Member is thereby obliged to speak; there is no compulsive speaking in this Assembly.

    Mr Speaker: That is not a point of order. There is, of course, freedom of speech and the Member for Queenstown can, of course, attack this motion. He is probably going on a different tack. The Member for Anson wishes for a postponement, but the Member for Queenstown considers this is not sufficient time, I suppose.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: You see, Sir, even here he tries to muzzle me.

    The Prime Minister: To try to help you.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Of course, he realises that ultimately it may be that it does not help because he has already sold out Singapore and he has already promised to sell out Singapore on time. That is why we have this guillotine. I am sure if the Prime Minister were honest to the people of Singapore; he would inform the people what he has actually promised. Is it because he has already promised the Federation that he would hand over Singapore by a certain date?

    Mr Speaker: Order. Let us come back to the guillotine motion, and the only debate can be as to whether or not there should be sufficient time. Dr Lee, nothing further?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: No.

    The Prime Minister: All I need say to the Member for Anson is that I am obliged to him for reminding the House that we gave more than ample time in our guillotine motion on the recommittal of the Bill, and I am obliged to him further in his agreeing with our estimation that there is more than ample time for the guillotine on this motion.

    Sir I will be happy to postpone the moving of this motion till Tuesday provided he promises me his wholehearted support and asures me that we finish even before Tuesday.

    Mr Speaker: I thought the Member said the 10th, i.e. Monday.

    The Prime Minister: I beg your Pardon - Tuesday.

Column: 922



    Mr Speaker: Yes. The 10th is Tuesday.

    Mr David Marshall: The suggestion, Sir, was that the motion should be moved on Tuesday for effect on Wednesday as suggested.

    Mr Speaker: Can I suggest that since there might be great disagreement, we take a resolution today? It makes no difference. If it is going to be finished on Tuesday, well it is finished on Tuesday.

    The Prime Minister: I am much obliged to you for drawing the logical conclusion - of our respective positions, Mr Speaker, and I bow to your ruling.

    Mr Speaker: I think the Prime Minister must not mistake the Chair. There is no ruling at all. It is just a suggestion that we might save some time on Tuesday anyway. Perhaps there might be a debate on that motion an Tuesday.

    Mr David Marshall: Then, Sir, may I move, That this motion do stand adjourned to Tuesday, the 10th July, 1962.

    The Prime Minister: May I, Sir, in view of the fact that you gave no such ruling, gratefully accept your suggestion, and suggest to the Member for Anson that perhaps some valuable time on Tuesday which might otherwise be used for elaborating some of the finer points of argument of the Member, for Queenstown would otherwise be lost, in his once again trying to feel obliged to have to say something on that motion. I have already saved, himself a few minutes this afternoon and I think we should save himself a few other minutes on Tuesday.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.

    Mr Speaker: Does the Member for Anson insist? I might say that these guillotine motions are not unusual in any Parliament.

    Mr Marshall indicated he did not insist.

    Question put, and agreed to.

FINAL APPROPRIATION (1961) BILL


    Order for Second and Third Readings read.

2.46 p.m.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's recommendation that this Bill be proceeded with. I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, pursuant to section 97 (2) of the, Singapore (Constitution) Order in Council, 1958, the Finance Minister shall, after the end of each financial year, introduce into the Assembly a Final Appropriation Bill pertaining to such items which have not, yet, been included in any Appropriation Bill.

    Supplementary, estimates totalling $100,523,174 were submitted and approved by the Assembly in 1961 The Bill seeks to live legal cover to these supplementary estimates.

    Sir I beg to move.

    Question put and agreed to

    Bill accordingly read a Second time.
Third Reading


    Mr Speaker: Will the Minister proceed with the Third Reading?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, I beg to move, That the Bill be now read a Third time.

    Question put and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Third time and passed.

SINGAPORE NATIONAL
REFERENDUM BILL
Order for resumed Third Reading

    Mr Speaker: The original Question was, "That the Bill be now read a Third time." Since which an amendment has been proposed to leave out from "That" to the end of the Question and to add instead thereof-

"this Assembly, conscious that this Bill was introduced for the purpose of holding a Referendum to ascertain the wishes of the people in relation to the issue of reunification of Singapore and the Federation of Malaya, declines to give it a third reading on the ground that the provisions therein are inappropriate and inadequate for that purpose".

    Question again proposed, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out."

    Mr Speaker: Dr Lee Siew Choh had the Floor.

2.50 p.m.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I was saying last night, this Referendum Bill has been the object of severe attack from all sections of the, people and from all strata of society in Singapore. Office workers, factory workers farmers, students, the intelligentsia, both English-educated, and Chinese educated, businessmen, professional men, all have joined in condemnation of this undemocratic, unjust, unfair and dishonest Referendum Bill. The odium and the Fascist nature of the Bill are clearly evident. There is hardly anyone in Singapore today who can stand up and honestly say that this is a democratic, fair and honest Bill.

    The Member for Anson called it an abortion fathered by dishonesty out of ineptitude I wish it was true Sir but I say it is not an abortion. An abortion, Sir is something born dead.

    An hon. Member: You are an expert.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: It is something not even properly formed when born, Therefore, the more appropriate word for this Bill is not abortion but a monster. Sir, in medical parlance, a monster

Column: 925

is something that comes out from the womb and can still be alive. An abortion is dead. You do not see it any more. Therefore, this Bill is a monster born out of dishonesty and Fascist dictatorship. It is a monster which will be born alive because of the somersault of the S.P.A., but a monster which even the dishonest and dictatorial P.A.P. themselves, the parents of this monster, cannot keep alive for very long. This monster of a Bill will only become law for the execution and sell-out of the people of Singapore, and the dishonest P.A.P. parents are themselves so ashamed of this monster that they will have to kill it immediately after their dirty work has been done. It is too indecent for parade and has to be kept away from public view.

    Sir, amongst the political Parties represented in this House, the Workers' Party, the United People's Party and the Barisan Sosialis have all condemned this Bill. And until the critical hour not so very long ago, even the S.P.A. had been loud in condemnation of the dishonesty in clause 29 of the Bill. The S.P.A. unfortunately -

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): On a point of order, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Point of order, yes.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh resumed his seat.

    Mr Rajah: Is all this relevant to the motion before the House?

    Mr Speaker: I suppose that every Member is entitled to an exordium. But I think the Member for Queenstown is now going back to the debate on clause 29 which has already been concluded. He must now concentrate his efforts on indicating to the House how he thinks clause 29 or any other clause is inappropriate or inadequate for the purpose of holding a referendum. We do not want to near any debate for or against any particular clause in this motion in principle.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: It hurts the Member for Farrer Park -

Column: 926



    Mr Speaker: The Member for Queenstown has been ruled out of order. That part of his speech is out of order.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I merely wanted to point out, Sir, that had the S.P.A. not joined in the dishonesty of the P.A.P., possibly through pressure from-

    Mr Speaker: Order. That all is too late. That speech should have been made when we were discussing clause 29. I think I have said this before and I will say it again, Members must accept the fact that these clauses have been written into the Bill. Whether they like those clauses or not makes no difference. These clauses have been written into the Bill. Members must now show how they think those clauses are inappropriate or inadequate.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Let me preface this, Sir, by saying that even outside this House all the other political Parties, whatever their political beliefs and policies, have come out openly against this Bill, because everyone in Singapore now recognises that this Fascist Bill of the P.A.P. has infringed the very basic aid inherent right of individual free choice and of the individual right to say "no". For example, the Liberal-Socialists, the Parts Rakyat, the United Democratic Party, the Workers' Party and the Barisan Sosialis, although they have different political ideologies and different platforms, have nevertheless, in the face of this common danger, joined together and formed a Council of Joint Action. We had hoped, Sir, that this Council of Joint Action might influence the Government to give up their Fascist ways and possibly put the interest of the people above the interests of the few Ministers. Even professional bodies, from doctors, dental surgeons, pharmacists and journalists, have come out with strong statements condemning the dishonesty and the undemocratic provisions in the Bill. Everywhere we go, Sir, in buses-

    Mr Speaker: Order. I really hate having to interrupt the hon. Member because I know how strongly he feels in these matters, but he must realise that we are on the Third Reading. He is now

Column: 927

advancing an argument against the clauses in the Bill when they were drafted. He must now accept the position that this Assembly has accepted those clauses. The position now is that there is a motion to decline to give this Bill a Third Reading. And the reason for that is that in the view of some Members those clauses are inappropriate or inadequate for the specific purpose which has been declared, and that is for the purpose of holding a referendum. That is the position. We have finished with the Second Reading debate. We have finished with the Committee stage; we are now on the Third Reading, and the, debate on the Third Reading must be confined to the contents of the Bill as they are there now.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I realise, Sir, that it is not permissible, if we go according to the usual rules of debate, to harp back on things we have spoken before. But, Sir, the P.A.P. Ministers must know what is happening outside this House as well. This has a direct bearing on out discussions here in this House, and if we do not take the feelings and views outside the House into consideration, then we may be ignoring a large section of opinion and be merely discussing the subject with a limited view.

    Mr Speaker: Order. The opinions outside this House were relevant when we were discussing the Bill in principle. When we were debating on the Second Reading, those opinions were very relevant; when we were discussing The Bill in Committee, those opinions were very relevant. Now, as I say, we are in the position where the Bill has gone through Committee and has come up for a Third Reading. All that Members can do now is to refer to the contents of the Bill and say this clause, that clause, is inappropriate or inadequate, and cannot be used properly for the purpose which has been declared, that is, for the purpose of holding a referendum. If there are opinions which the Member would like to express as to why they are inappropriate or inadequate, then, of course, he is entitled to give those opinions.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I will come to that by and by, Sir. But allow me to remind the Ministers opposite of what the

Column: 928

people outside are saying. The Ministers have been hiding behind air-conditioned rooms and Radio P.A.P. and they have not -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I wonder if the Member could point to a certain clause in this Bill which indicates that Ministers are in air-conditioned rooms, working under easy conditions and so on. What has that to do with the Third Reading?

    An hon. Member: Air-conditioned Chamber!

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: My point is this, Sir, that if they had gone to meet the people outside and had heard what they said, they would not have pursued the course they are taking today.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Yes, all that would have been relevant, as I say, before the Third Reading. But now we are on the Third Reading of this Bill. Let us be relevant.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I will come to it straightaway, Sir. But just one sentence to let the P.A.P. know-

    Mr Speaker: Order. If that sentence is a continuation of previous sentences, that sentence must be disallowed.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Sir, this sentence can be related to so many things at the same time, but definitely it will be related to clause 29, because the people are saying there is nothing dirtier than the P.A.P. today. In Hokkien, the words they use are Chin Chia Chow.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Goh Chew Chua): Shut up!

    Mr Speaker: Order. I heard a Member on the Government side taking objection to that expression. Well, I do not know what that expression means. If the Member on the Government side would like to tell the Chair what that expression means and how that expression is offensive, then I will have to make a ruling on it.

    Mr Goh Chew Chua: Sir, the leader of the Barisan says Chin Chia Chow which means very bad. What makes him say it is very bad?

Column: 929



    Mr Speaker: Order. First let the Chair know the meaning of that expression. That is not Mandarin. I do rot know whether there is a Mandarin equivalent. I think he says it is Hokkien. Now, let us have the meaning of it, unless it is so bad that the Parliamentary Secretary does not wish to give me the meaning.

    Mr Goh Chew Chua: Sir, in Hokkien it is very bad. He says that the people are saying the Party is very, very bad. Does he mean to say he comes here-

    Mr Speaker: Order. So the meaning of that expression is "very, very bad"?

    Mr Goh Chew Chua: Yes.

    Mr Speaker: I do not think that is disorderly. It is not unparliamentary.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister -

    Mr Speaker: Order. Let us carry on.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - for his kind explanation, Sir.

    Sir, this Bill, as we have said before, has no parallel in history. It is, to use the words of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister, so dirty and unprecedented that the Bill, after it has become law and has done its dirty deed, will have to be repealed immediately. From this alone, Sir, we can see the dishonesty and Fascist nature of the Bill. It is like a traitorous murderer, after the shameful and traitorous deed has been done, wanting hurriedly to get rid of all evidence, of that instrument, that has been used for the treacherous and shameful deed. It is like the P.A.P., after they have plunged a knife into the hearts of the people of Singapore, wanting to get rid of this knife as soon as possible. But let us ask them, where can this evidence, this Bill or this law, or this knife, where can this evidence be hidden? The knife, Sir, can be buried in the bowels of the earth or thrown into the deep sea and may not be found again. But this Bill, Sir, this referendum law as it will be, will forever be recorded in the annals of history as the foulest and the most shameful act of treachery of the P.A.P. leadership and

Column: 930

all those who condone and connive at such treachery. Sir, we have spent many days of debate on this Bill. There were five days of it in Select Committee and another seven days in the Legislative Assembly on the Second Reading and on recommittal. No Bill in the history of Singapore has been so controversial or has been the object of so much adverse criticism. Why? Because it is a most undemocratic, unfair, unjust and most dishonest Bill. The Member for Anson has given many examples of the dishonesty of the P.A.P. The P.A.P. Ministers themselves know this, and they know they cannot justify their undemocratic principles embodied in the various undemocratic clauses of the Bill. So, time and time again in Select Committee, the P.A.P. Ministers had to defend themselves with evasive and irrelevant arguments. Whenever the Ministers were cornered, whenever they could find no more excuses, they sought refuge in their stock-in-trade answer, "This is a general Referendum Bill." They talk of toddy shops, they talk of tobacco smoking, pipe smoking, cigarette smoking, and they keep on repeating, "This is a general Referendum Bill. This is a general Referendum Bill." Altogether I have counted about 30 times their saying this in Select Committee. Even in this Assembly, the Deputy Prime Minister tried to pull the same stunt again. He said, "This is a general Referendum Bill." The only unfortunate part was that he did not know that we had referred to all this before. He was out of the Assembly Chamber and he came in stuttering those same silly excuses. Yet all along in their arguments, and especially when we were discussing clause 5 of the Bill, they indicated that this Bill was meant for merger. They said we had had enough discussion and canvassing on the merger issue as we had house-to-house canvassing, rallies and discussion groups long, long before. Therefore, they considered there was enough time for canvassing. But when the arguments suited them, they came out openly admitting that this Bill is specifically a Referendum Bill for merger. The Minister for Finance especially came out blatantly and said, "Let us come down to brass tacks. This Bill will be for merger." Similarly. I had occasion

Column: 931

to quote, during the Second Reading, the Minister for Home Affairs and the Deputy Prime Minister all saying that the present Referendum Bill is for merger. I think the Member for Anson referred to the Government amending his motion in April and the wording of the amendment specifically said that this Bill is meant for merger. Altogether, Sir, both in Select Committee and in the examples I have quoted, they have said 20 times that this is a Bill for merger. So if you cancel the two figures out, 30 against 20, it sounds as if it ultimately should turn out to be a general Referendum Bill - 30 times general Referendum Bill, 20 times specific Bill. But now we have the final admission from the Minister for Home Affairs that this Bill is going to be for merger. They are going to scrap the Bill, scrap the law immediately after the dirty work has been done. They are too ashamed to keep it after merger any more. This shows the utter dishonesty of the P.A.P. and the twists and turns of the P.A.P. Ministers.

    The Member for Anson gave a series of detailed quotations. I do not think it is necessary for me to bore you with those very same quotations again. But I would like to bring the House back to the time when the Select Committee requested views from the public. If you remember, Sir, advertisements were in serted in the newspapers and all views and memoranda were supposed to be submitted by the 6th April. There were altogether 12 meetings, daily from 2.30 to 7.30 p.m., sometimes 8 o'clock, and much time and energy was spent in the taking of oral evidence. Much play was made of the credentials of those who made representations.

    Mr Speaker: Order. That is completely irrelevant. The Member for Queenstown must know that that is irrelevant to the Third Reading. I take it he is coming to the point where these people were met with the suggestion that this was a general Referendum Bill. If that is so, all he need say is that that was so, and pass on to the next topic.
